text:
Union Square East, north from East 14th Street, showing the Henry K. Browne equestrian Washington Statue facing west- ward towards the Park. The latter is on the left and extends to East 17th Street where appears the old Everett House. North of that point, this thoroughfare becomes Fourth Avenue.

View 1: 1859

Brown Brothers

View 2: February 1906

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [George Washington Statue.]

text:
Union Square East, north from East 14th Street, showing the Henry K. Browne equestrian Washington Statue facing west- ward towards the Park. The latter is on the left and extends to East 17th Street where appears the old Everett House. North of that point, this thoroughfare becomes Fourth Avenue.

View 1: 1859

Brown Brothers

View 2: February 1906

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [George Washington Statue.]

text:
Union Square: A view northward across the Park from East 14th Street (foreground) and Union Square East (right). Note the Equestrian Washington, the work of Henry K. Browne in the circle. This is now (1937) located in the Park, being moved to its present site about 1930. 1898.

Gift of M. Van Der Weyde.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - [14th Street (East) - George Washington Statue.]

text: Union Square East, north from East 14th to 17th Streets (where it becomes Fourth Ave.), showing the Park on the left and across same a row of buildings on East 17th Street; the latter forming the northern boundary. Materials shown in the foreground are for subway construction. April 5, 1901.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - Between 14th and 17th Streets (East) - [Union Square Park.]

text:
Union Square Park: A northward view from East 14th Street, showing this open area bounded at the left, by Union Square West (Broadway), in the center, by East 17th Street and in the foreground, by Union Square East (Fourth Avenue).

The equestrian Washington monument was removed about 1932 to the Park proper. Close observation will show a political banner on Fourth Avenue bearing the names of Theodore Roosevelt and Charles Fairbanks.

1904

Ewing Galloway
title: Manhattan: Union Square Park - [Union Square - 14th Street (East) - George Washington Statue.]
